# Sensor current is 100nA--10uA # In Amperes I = float(random.randrange(100,10000,1))/1e9 # In uA Iu = I*1e6
# Leakage resistance is 1MOhm--2MOhm Rp = float(random.randrange(10,20,1))*1e5 # In MOhms RpM = Rp/1e6
# Series resistance is between 10kOhm and 20kOhm # In kOhms RsK = float(random.randrange(10,20,1)) # In Ohms Rs = RsK*1e3
# Loaded by 100kOhm indicator circuit Rl = 1e5 RlK = Rl/1e3
Vt = I*Rp Rt = Rp+2*Rs In = Vt/Rt
RtM = Rt/1e6
Vl = (Vt*Rl)/(Rl+Rt)
A certain light sensor is modeled as a current source that produces a current proportional to the intensity of light falling on it. There is leakage through the sensor, modeled by a resistor \(R_p=$RpM\)M\(\Omega\) in parallel with the current source. There is resistance in the contacts to the sensor, modeled by the series resistances \(R_s=$RsK\)k\(\Omega\). In this experiment the light produces a current of \(I=$Iu\mu\)A.
It is useful to summarize this model by constructing a Thevenin equivalent circuit for it.
What is the Thevenin voltage (in Volts) \(V_{TH}\) of the sensor?
What is the Thevenin resistance (in M\(\Omega\)) \(R_{TH}\) of the sensor?
The sensor is intended to be used in a light meter. In this application the output of the sensor is connected to a system that amplifies the signal and displays it, scaled to appropriate units.
The amplifier is designed to present a resistance of \(R_L=$RlK\)k\(\Omega\). So, from the point of view of the sensor we can model it as just a resistor.
What is the voltage (in Volts) \(V_L\) presented to the amplifier?
Note that the circuit connecting the sensor to the amplifier and display does not care about the insides of either the sensor or of the the amplifier and display. So we don't have to consider those complications to compute the properties of their interconnection. This is the modeling power of the Thevenin idea!
